abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, but with only modest
            institutional development impacts. While the piloting nature
            of a Learning and Innovation Loan proved to be particularly
            appropriate in a new sector and an uncertain setting, where
            experimentation and testing of innovative approaches - i.e.
            especially in the Saxon village development - are essential,
            the selection process for pilot villages however, would have
            benefited from a more comprehensive community consultative
            effort earlier in the process, to include clearer selection
            criteria. In addition to reinforcing the need for community
            consultation and participation, established monitoring and
            evaluation mechanisms, and a strong supervision, several
            lessons are addressed as follows. Given the importance and
            uniqueness of cultural assets, and the patrimony regulations
            that govern their management and use in most countries,
            there are inevitable, and understandable clearance and
            approvals at various levels, that result in unexpected
            execution delays. The nature of these processes is
            significantly different from those experienced in most
            Bank-supported sectors; e.g., the processes involve several
            layers of review by art historians, restoration experts, and
            other specialists inside, and outside the Government. This
            factor must be taken more into account at the initial
            project design.
